articles.headline: Rule Allows U.S. a Close Look at Big Hedge Funds
articles.snippet: The rule adopted Wednesday requires large funds to report details of their holdings in a bid to limit risks to the financial system.
articles.abstract: The rule adopted Wednesday requires large funds to report details of their holdings in a bid to limit risks to the financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Large hedge funds, the very private investment outfits that borrow money to magnify their big financial bets, will be required for the first time to report detailed information on their investments and borrowings under a rule adopted by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday.

articles.headline: For This Menace, Only One Thing to Do: Ready, Aim, Fireworks!
articles.snippet: Terre Haute, Ind., shares a problem with Auburn, N.Y., and Lancaster, Pa.: Crows. Lots and lots of crows.
articles.abstract: Terre Haute, Ind., shares a problem with Auburn, N.Y., and Lancaster, Pa.: Crows. Lots and lots of crows.

articles.headline: A Welcome Windows Phone
articles.snippet: Microsoft’s software answer to Android and the iPhone first appeared, incomplete, about a year ago. The blanks have been filled in: speech recognition, Twitter integration and app updates.
articles.abstract: Microsoft’s software answer to Android and the iPhone first appeared, incomplete, about a year ago. The blanks have been filled in: speech recognition, Twitter integration and app updates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Did you hear the news? A new model of a certain black, rectangular, touch-screen smartphone has just arrived. Its new software contains what the company says are hundreds of new features. The most eye-popping enhancement is speech recognition: you can tell this new phone to call someone, text someone or give you driving directions.

articles.headline: Facing Hardship, Jobless Still Say They Have Hope
articles.snippet: A New York Times/CBS News poll found that despite enduring hardships and pessimism about the economy, unemployed Americans were optimistic about landing a job.
articles.abstract: A New York Times/CBS News poll found that despite enduring hardships and pessimism about the economy, unemployed Americans were optimistic about landing a job.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s lingering unemployment crisis has forced many people without work to dip into their savings, borrow from relatives and do without necessities including health insurance, and most people who receive unemployment benefits said that the money was not enough to meet their basic needs, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll of jobless Americans.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Allison Kopicki

articles.headline: Ruth Madoff Says Couple Tried Suicide in 2008
articles.snippet: Bernard Madoff’s wife said she and her husband tried to kill themselves just after his Ponzi scheme was exposed.
articles.abstract: Bernard Madoff’s wife said she and her husband tried to kill themselves just after his Ponzi scheme was exposed.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Christmas Eve 2008, two weeks after Bernard L. Madoff confessed to running history’s largest Ponzi scheme, he and his wife, Ruth, attempted suicide in their Manhattan penthouse.

articles.headline: China Reins In Entertainment and Blogging
articles.snippet: Communist leaders are proposing some of the tightest limits on media and Internet freedoms in years.
articles.abstract: Communist leaders are proposing some of the tightest limits on media and Internet freedoms in years.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Political censorship in this authoritarian state has long been heavy-handed. But for years, the Communist Party has tolerated a creeping liberalization in popular culture, tacitly allowing everything from popular knockoffs of “American Idol”-style talent shows to freewheeling microblogs that let media groups prosper and let people blow off steam.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere, Michael Wines and Edward Wong

articles.headline: Lawyer Opposing Health Law Is Familiar Face to the Justices
articles.snippet: Paul D. Clement, who has appeared before the Supreme Court 49 times, for the government and against, is likely to add one more case — the challenge to the health care overhaul law.
articles.abstract: Paul D. Clement, who has appeared before the Supreme Court 49 times, for the government and against, is likely to add one more case — the challenge to the health care overhaul law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It would be hard for any lawyer to fathom a more riveting caseload than the one Paul D. Clement carried during his seven years in President George W. Bush’s Justice Department.

articles.headline: Black Voters’ Support for Obama Is Steady and Strong
articles.snippet: President Obama’s standing remains remarkably strong among African-Americans, but Democrats say turning out those voters in 2012 remains a challenge.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s standing remains remarkably strong among African-Americans, but Democrats say turning out those voters in 2012 remains a challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Abdul Malik seems the prototype of a disenchanted Barack Obama voter.

articles.headline: Shares Jump on European Deal to Solve Debt Crisis
articles.snippet: Even as investors extended a rally in stocks, some credit markets barely budged, indicating continued doubts about a long-term fix for the debt crisis.
articles.abstract: Even as investors extended a rally in stocks, some credit markets barely budged, indicating continued doubts about a long-term fix for the debt crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: World financial markets powered higher on Thursday in the giddy hope that Europe’s plan to solve its sovereign debt crisis would finally lift the uncertainty over the global economy and markets. In the United States, a sharp jump in stocks continued what has become the biggest monthly rally in 37 years.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Christine Hauser

articles.headline: U.S. Economy Picks Up Pace, Averting a Stall
articles.snippet: Gross domestic product grew at a 2.5 percent annual rate in the third quarter, an improvement but not enough to recover ground lost during the recession.
articles.abstract: Gross domestic product grew at a 2.5 percent annual rate in the third quarter, an improvement but not enough to recover ground lost during the recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: Economic growth in the United States picked up in the last quarter in the latest encouraging sign that the recovery, while painfully slow, had not stalled.

articles.headline: Calling Bankers’ Bluff, Merkel Won Europe a Debt Plan
articles.snippet: In the end, it was Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Nicolas Sarkozy of France against the European banking establishment — and the bankers blinked.
articles.abstract: In the end, it was Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Nicolas Sarkozy of France against the European banking establishment — and the bankers blinked.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — In the end, it was Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Nicolas Sarkozy of France against the European banking establishment — and the bankers blinked.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Stephen Castle
